text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new an autumn
for crippled children review try not to
destroy everything you love this is the
4th full-length LP that hails from an
experimental metal outfit that hails
from the Netherlands they've been
dropping a new album every year since
2010 this band started as a really
depressive black metal outfit with a
super noisy and claustrophobic recording
and even though that recording style has
stuck with them on each new release that
hasn't really stopped them from
experimenting with sound and additional
instrumentation like strings and scents
the strings played an especially big
role on their last full-length LP and I
think these guys have grown
compositionally as well writing songs
that are a lot less dismal this record
is pretty rich with melody melodies that
are triumphant occasionally or even
pretty and sweet on the ear despite the
recording in the end the vocals on top
of this instrumentation being so harsh
typically I don't really mind the
grading harsh wretched black metal vocal
style but I do wish the singing brought
some more variety to the table on this
record and I wish it wasn't so buried in
the mix on numerous songs here too but
still how claustrophobic the recording
on this record is it brings a bit of a
unique challenge it's interesting to see
how Magnum of an opus the band can pack
into such a tiny space with guitars and
drums and vocals and strings and since
all clashing against one another
violently however it's not like the mix
or the way this recording was assembled
is messy the band makes room for
essential sounds when they need to like
the wispy string melodies that pop in on
the song never complete as soon as those
introduce themselves it seems that
everything else is absolutely quiet so
that you can hear the theme melody that
they are introducing and even though the
sound of this track is really low Phi it
doesn't stop this musical moment from
feeling so huge and cinematic it's like
watching autumn leaves fall dramatically
in slow motion as someone who you've
loved so much for a good chunk of your
life is walking away into the distance
some tracks here
features some really innocent chiming
piano chords that kicks the song off and
and really sets a fragile tone like on
the song sepia mountains for her lament
these pianos play through the
introduction until basically a wall of
guitars comes down and crushes them
after which the band moves through all
these slow fuzzy guitars and I think
with how beautiful and delicate and
grainy some of the sounds are on this
record a lot of people are going to hear
what's going on with this LP and compare
instantly to the latest LPS from
deafheaven
or I'll say and I do think these albums
have common ground I think they could
share common fans but I also think that
an autumn for crippled children finds a
way to make themselves stick out in this
lighter shade of black metal we've been
seeing lately why a lot of tracks on
this LP deliver some epic builds that
that tug at the heartstrings not a
single song on this album goes over the
six-minute mark over all the songs on
this release are pretty straightforward
direct and to-the-point and these guys
pack just about as much detail into
their songs as the other two artists I
just mentioned but they stick so
passionately to that Lofa aesthetic and
I think this band actually experiments a
little bit more with genre then it would
seem simply on the surface of these
tracks - for example with a really
strong icy sense in the driving bass and
drum groove on the opening track here
the only thing that is stopping the song
from being a post-punk track are the
vocals there are a lot of moments on
this LP though that drink from that
black gaze Punchbowl as well really
thick walls of instrumentation swirling
into itself really dreamy harsh but
seductive and the band manages to build
the tension really high with guitars
strings keyboards and drums just playing
more and more intensely as the track
moves along songs like the woods are on
fire and never complete and these tracks
feature some really memorable melodies -
however I do get let down a little bit
by some of the songs here when I feel
like the track maybe cycling through
sort of a stereotypical post-rock build
or chord progression with a lot of
blobby syrupy instrumentation that feels
a little formless it's a bit like a
build that go
to nowhere it's a bill that loses its
flavor about halfway up the escalation
issues like this create a bit of a dry
spell in the middle of the LP for me but
the album does pick up again with song
closer the song that features these
slowly ascending guitar leads that are
tremolo picked going up and up against
these thunderous drum beats eventually
these harmonized whaling guitars sort of
scream into the mix and create a really
nice change of pace and even though I
like tracks like this that are
constantly moving upward and onward I do
wish there were some more songs here
that were just more direct and visceral
and aggressive and immediate like the
opening track on here I can't help but
feel like on the whole this album is
just one bill that leads to another bill
that leads to another bill which isn't
necessarily a bad thing especially if
the instrumentation is played well I
mean after all that deafheaven record
that came out recently does sort of seem
to thrive off of that formula as well
but with the builds and the
instrumentation being raised so high on
this record right here and the low-fiber
cording just crushing it to such a low
it does dampen a little bit of the
excitement of the potential excitement
all too often I think the the haziness
of the recordings on this LP leave some
of these songs feeling just a little too
Sammy Sammy
even if the sound is very appealing to
an extent even if a lot of the melodies
on this thing are really catchy I dug
this record a lot I do think these guys
could be a band to watch as far as this
musical style goes I'm feeling a light a
decent seven on this thing transition if
you've given this record to listen what
did you think of it did you love it hate
it why what do you think I should review
next the heat
forever
